Evaluation_Questions: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken
What is your overall assessment of this course
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor
The primary instructor's provided students with helpful and timely feedback
The instructor established a positive learning environment
The instructor raised questions or problems that encouraged me to think critically
Comments_Questions: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved
Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not
Comments_List: 5 hours on weeks with homework assignments but maybe 10 hours for studying for midterms
5 hrs per week
Approximately 5-10 hours per week
6 hours per week
2 hours/week
5-8 hours per week for homework and 20+ for exams
5-10 hours per homework, additional hours during midterms and final
5 hours
4 hr/week
3h
6h
5 hours one average, more if we had an exam
6 hours
10 hours
at least 10 hrs per week

This course was mediocre. It was organized well. I felt that the teaching assistants were really prepared and always had lessons which nicely complimented lecture. The homework assignments really helped my understanding. Lectures were very bad. It was difficult to ask questions.

Great course to take! Built on foundational knowledge of epi concepts we touched up on from Epi 1. Lecture notes can be incredibly text-heavy, making it difficult for students to breakdown concepts. Exam questions can also be very tricky

Strengths: 
- Incredibly knowledgable teaching fellows 
- TF Slides provided great summaries of course info

Weaknesses: 
- Text heavy lecture slides 
- Lack of straightforward wording on exams 
- Few opportunities to engage with material during lecture

A very important course for laying a strong epidemiology foundation. While the course is an important one, class was not engaging. It mainly consisted of the professor reading off of the slides. However, there is weekly homework that helps you master the material, and this was integral to my success. The TFs were lifesavers. They created section slides to summarize each week's lecture material with easy-to-understand explanations and practice problems.

The course was very well designed and well taught. Weekly sections were a strength of the course because students were constantly reviewing the material and practicing answering questions/performing calculations. The problem sets were challenging and reinforced course material. This made exam preparation easier and improved my understanding of the material. Overall, I do not think the course could be improved. The teaching fellows were excellent and their review slides/jeopardy-style reviews were very helpful as well.

Strength: This lectures covers the basic and advanced topic of EPI in detail, and the contents are very easy to understand.
Weakness: Dr. Risch speaks too fast.
too much regurgitation of information.

I basically self-taught and was thankful to have an excellent professor for Epi I that contributed to my success in this course. To improve, you should get an instructor that actually wants to teach an intermediate/ beginner epidemiology course. Professor Risch's uninterested nature came through during our lectures exemplified by his reading verbatim off of the slides and adding nothing of value to lecture.
The course content is useful for a student majoring in epidemiology. But it  would be nicer if the professor could convey it in a more attracting way.

The beginning of this course was slow. Prof. Risch just read off the slides, so by the end of the class very few people attended lectures. The TAs were the saving grace of this class. I did almost all my learning through them--their slides and section materials. It's disappointing because this is really important information for future public health practitioners to know.
terrible lectures, good problem sets
Better lecture style

Strengths: really builds onto epi 1 knowledge and is a great class to learn more about epi (also a requirement for CDE). the homeworks really helped in understanding the material more, and so did the TFs, and the exams.
Weaknesses: confusion of exam 2 content up until the night before the exam, sometimes questions on exams were unfair and not representative of material covered in class

The course is very informative and useful in real study environment. It contains contents from biostatistics and ammie and teaches it in a more thorough way. But the slides of the course is sometimes confusing and inaccessible. Overall this course is great.
I have learned so much. I just wish that my performance reflected that.
Technical term-heavy main course content, but manageable homeworks and exams.

Strengths - discussion sessions and homework useful for understanding and interpreting concepts learned in class, interesting concepts to understand intermediate level epidemiology
Weaknesses - no interaction with the professor, depth of knowledge too much for what was expected on tests
The course is great. You can learn a lot in this class.
Good
I appreciate that this class did build on the foundations from Epi I.
Great course

Strengths: Gave me a solid understanding of epidemiologic concepts and how to apply these
Weaknesses: I think possibly spending some more time on key areas like confounding and interaction and dropping the applied health research classes would have been beneficial for my learning

This is a great class! The class material are useful, the lecture slides are (wordy but) well-explained, and the TFs are extremely dedicated and helpful! The Friday discussion sessions review the concepts covered in the lectures and summarizes the key points, and they are helpful for solving the p-sets. The exams are a little bit challenging though. There were several multiple choices in each midterm that worth too many points. The all or nothing nature of multiple choices made it hard to get a good grade for the exam. But the issue resolved for the final. I can see that the professor and TFs really values the feedbacks from students. Overall, it's a great class!

This course invokes critical thinking, which benefited most for me. It provides me with new angles to consider the existing methods. One thing can be improved is that the class could be more engaging. It's a pity that some of my classmates couldn't engage in this provoking course. I also like the discussion session, which clarified most of my questions.
Overall good class, although exams were needlessly nit picky and attending class wasn't helpful.

Epi II was the most frustratingly, poorly taught course I have ever encountered in my entire life and a reason that I have told people not to attend the Yale School of Public Health out of the simple fact that such a fundamental course on epidemiology was so abominably sub-par. I cannot begin to express my sheer frustration with the fact that my $60,000 is going towards this course and the instruction directing it-- my only suggestion for those who will be forced to endure this course-- SPEAK UP. However, since no one in the administration legitimately reads or takes seriously the responses of these evaluations (otherwise Harvey would not be teaching any course), let me air my grievances for my own sanity by providing objective explanations for why this course was so utterly terrible: [1] monotone, painfully boring lectures: the lecture material was presented in such an unengaging apathetic, indifferent tone (with the exception of Harvey's demeaning and pretentious comments that I will get to later) that pretty much everyone stopped showing up to class; [2] confusing, uninformative lecture slides: even the TAs told us not to look at the lecture slides because they were so opaque and difficult to get through; [3] intentionally deceitful and ridiculously absurd exam questions: I have never in my entire life had as much difficulty comprehending exam questions as I have in Epi II. The exam questions were so poorly worded and constructed that the TFs even admitted they would not have arrived at some of the answers. In particular, some of his questions required extrapolation that was not even remotely feasible based on the knowledge we were presented in lecture. His rationale for these questions is that he "wants us to think like epidemiologists" and that epidemiology is naturally a "nit-picky" science-- No, it is actually not. Epidemiology is actually quite straightforward. But Harvey made the discipline of epidemiology so ambiguous, more confusing than when I had started the course, to a point where I actually (and yes, I realize how terrible this is as an MPH student) despise the content of the course; [4] his derogatory, demeaning comments towards others in the field of public health and own colleagues-- Harvey's elitist mentality (ref. his email title) carried over to an insane degree in this course, where he often put down other epidemiologists because they approached things "incorrectly." I was drawn to public health out of the genuine good-will that public health researchers and practitioners have, but Harvey, whether intentionally or not, characterized a very negative aspect of epi research. Yet, as frustrated as I am by this course and Harvey's instruction, I almost feel that YSPH is more to blame. I actually feel that Harvey does not realize how poorly taught this course was and do feel that he is genuinely a good guy who wants us all to appreciate epi. I am more frustrated by YSPH, who should either obtain an effective instructor for this required course or provide Harvey the resources that he needs to become a more competent instructor. Lastly, the TFs were an immensely redeeming quality of this course and were the most approachable, incredible group who imparted so much knowledge on this course. I don't know what I would have done without them but truly hope that YSPH seriously and critically evaluates this course for the future.... since it clearly hasn't been done yet.
I appreciated the recordings of the lectures. I think the midterms/finals were a bit more complicated than what was taught in class and we should be given more time to complete the midterms.
The course is finepsets are reasonable and pertain to course material and exams but lectures are dry and not necessary to attend.

The class provides helpful insights for epidemiology studies, I enjoy the content and found much information very useful for my future study and research.  The workload is a little bit too much. The TF sessions are not that helpful, sometimes they are not that prepared and the sessions are too long (also too early in the morning)

Strengths:
Lecture slides were clear and informative
Lectures were recorded which was helpful for studying

Weakness:
Homework was extremely challenging and lengthy
Exam timing often did not line up with lectures covered on said exam
Material covered on exams was not clearly communicated
TFs and Professor often contradicted each other on course material
Exams assessed memory and not mastery of the material
Professor is too qualified to teach this course and gives dry lectures that very few students attend. Workload is manageable.

I think the course material was quite difficult, but that just comes with the field of epidemiology itself. The course may have relied a bit too much on the professor's way of thinking as the TF's often disagreed with his methods, which led to a lot of confusion.  The strength, though, comes in the fact that the course required an immense amount of individual thought instead of just regurgitating facts.

EXTREMELY DRY LECTURES
ASKED FOR TOO MUCH COMPLEX MATH

only required for CDE which makes no sense
good

The strengths of this course stemmed from the involvement of the TFs who did most of the teaching. They were all willing to put in extra effort to ensure that we understood and were fairly tested on the material. The weaknesses, on the other hand, stemmed from the professor, who delivered dry and engaging lectures in class. I truly wish that the class had examples that required involvement from the students but instead, Professor Risch read basically word-for-word from the slides and finished 20-40 minutes early during nearly every class period.

This course felt like a literal repeat of all the same material from epidemiology last semester up until the last month. I would have appreciated that we instead build from where we left off instead of wasting months relearning topics in the manners the professor preferred just because he preferred them and has no respect for the ways others practice epidemiology. The textbook we used did not feel helpful and lecture definitely was not helpful. The material was not broken down to digestible amounts at a time and when students asked the professor to explain something in a different way it seems like the professor believed he was doing that but his second or third explanation sounded no different from the first. The homework assignments were unrealistically long and complex, again, the textbook and attending lecture not once prepared me to complete problem sets without attending office hours too. Exam questions were often unclear and the recommendation we were given by some TFs was to essentially learn to read between the lines for the professor's specific preferences. That is not a form of learning I appreciate nor would consider learning. The lack of moral was clear in that students often never attended lecture at all. We needed more practice under lower risk circumstances in order to apply the knowledge of the course and not just memorize it. We also needed more examples of the material during lecture.

I can tell Dr. Risch is very smart. However, I think this may have gotten in the way of his teaching to beginning epidemiology students. He went too into the weeds on methodological concepts when we were first learning them to begin with. Also, his slides were just written blocks of text which made many question why they came to lecture.
Overall, good instructor. Very knowledgeable about epidemiology. You will learn a lot! Just be prepared for his text-heavy slides
I think overall Dr. Risch cares about his students and tries his best to make the material interesting and accessible to everyone.

It is obvious that Dr. Risch is exceptionally smart, but he is not always the most effective at conveying information to students. He mainly read off of slides, and there was a large dip in class attendance later in the semester likely because of this. Additionally, his slides tended to be very dense. They were often confusing and seemed better suited for higher level epidemiology students.

Dr. Risch had very detailed slides and was efficient with class time. He provided thoughtful insights throughout the course which I appreciated. At times, lectures felt a little bit rushed. Slowing down the pace of lectures (especially those that are calculation-heavy) would be beneficial.

Strength: Dr. Risch is extraordinary and feel really excited to take his course.
Weakness: Dr. Risch speaks too fast.
Less powerpoint and more discussion. We can learn from the powerpoint any time and in our own time.
Honestly, not great. He should not teach a beginner course.

He is very academic and professional, the message conveyed in the class is sound and clear. 
The weakness lies in the teaching style. It would be much better if the professor could emphasize the important concept with a different tone in class.

Prof. Risch is obviously very smart, but he's not very good at explaining things. He just read off the slides and I don't think he made any effort to simplify his language to make it more coherent. He's also not very receptive to feedback.
terrible lecturer - monotone and reads off slides

Prof. Risch is very knowledgeable, and it's clear that he's had a lot of experience in the field to challenge certain practices. He's deep down very nice and supportive of students, but at times I wish he separated his opinions from the actual material and presented students what the general scientific consensus is, especially since we're still in our early stage of our career. He definitely has a lot of opinions, but for students new to epi, there should be room for students to develop their own views about the material themselves. His quirks definitely got their way in how exam questions were written; at times it felt like we had to understand "Prof. Risch's language" as opposed to understanding certain terms in a more conventional way. He definitely cared about teaching and it was clear that he has spent a lot of time developing the material for the course. I wish he could be less opinionated sometimes and streamline material recycled from previous year to make the information more consistent since the course has been taught by different people.
Read off the slides a lot and provided a lot of detail that was sometimes confusing and not necessary for the scope of the class.

Dr Risch is a strong-headed, intelligent and knowledgeable epidemiologist. However, this often did not translate to easy instruction. his lectures were often too dense and slides were worded confusingly and unnecessarily complex. his lectures were often dry and the one on causal inference is too philosophical.
Strengths: helped me view epidemiology with a greater sense of appreciation
The instructor explains the question quite well. The overall pace of course is acceptable.
Prof Risch can be difficult in terms of the way he approaches assessments, but I know it is because he want to challenge us and prepare us as top tier epidemiologists.
Appreciated his math background and emphasis on making us think critically about common topics in epidemiology. Felt like his slides were a bit heavy sometimes.

The instructor should provide more opportunities for in class interaction and not rely on lengthy and detailed slides to portray all information. Potentially utilize poll everywhere to encourage participation.
An excellent instructor. He knows a lot and would like to discuss technical question with students.
Excellent
Might be better fit in upper level epidemiology courses, rather than Principles of Epidemiology II
Please write an epidemiology textbook!
Great

Strengths: An expert in the area, tried to convey the 'philosophical' side of epidemiology
Weaknesses: Classes were a little too much reading from slides, not much interaction and Q&A during the course of the class- which meant I mostly watched the video recordings rather than attending in person

For some topics, I found the classes quite confusing and actually learned the concepts better in section. I found that classes went into fine detail too quickly rather than starting with basic concepts then expanding on those

Exams sometimes focused on too much conceptual detail rather than the nuts and bolts knowledge that I expected to learn in this course.
Professor Risch is great! He is open to students' questions and you can tell that he put lots of efforts into making the lecture slides!

Prof. Risch is a smart person. His way of critical thinking benefits me a lot, providing me with new perspectives. He's also precise. One suggestion is that the class can be more engaging, with fewer paragraphs but more graphic illustrations.
Harvey has some interesting opinions about Epi and what he calls "science" he would benefit from some humble pie and from being a bit more open minded about his insanely specific exam questions.
Hope Prof. Harvey could speak louder or use the speaker.

Epi II was the most frustratingly, poorly taught course I have ever encountered in my entire life and a reason that I have told people not to attend the Yale School of Public Health out of the simple fact that such a fundamental course on epidemiology was so abominably sub-par. I cannot begin to express my sheer frustration with the fact that my $60,000 is going towards this course and the instruction directing it-- my only suggestion for those who will be forced to endure this course-- SPEAK UP. However, since no one in the administration legitimately reads or takes seriously the responses of these evaluations (otherwise Harvey would not be teaching any course), let me air my grievances for my own sanity by providing objective explanations for why this course was so utterly terrible: [1] monotone, painfully boring lectures: the lecture material was presented in such an unengaging apathetic, indifferent tone (with the exception of Harvey's demeaning and pretentious comments that I will get to later) that pretty much everyone stopped showing up to class; [2] confusing, uninformative lecture slides: even the TAs told us not to look at the lecture slides because they were so opaque and difficult to get through; [3] intentionally deceitful and ridiculously absurd exam questions: I have never in my entire life had as much difficulty comprehending exam questions as I have in Epi II. The exam questions were so poorly worded and constructed that the TFs even admitted they would not have arrived at some of the answers. In particular, some of his questions required extrapolation that was not even remotely feasible based on the knowledge we were presented in lecture. His rationale for these questions is that he "wants us to think like epidemiologists" and that epidemiology is naturally a "nit-picky" science-- No, it is actually not. Epidemiology is actually quite straightforward. But Harvey made the discipline of epidemiology so ambiguous, more confusing than when I had started the course, to a point where I actually (and yes, I realize how terrible this is as an MPH student) despise the content of the course; [4] his derogatory, demeaning comments towards others in the field of public health and own colleagues-- Harvey's elitist mentality (ref. his email title) carried over to an insane degree in this course, where he often put down other epidemiologists because they approached things "incorrectly." I was drawn to public health out of the genuine good-will that public health researchers and practitioners have, but Harvey, whether intentionally or not, characterized a very negative aspect of epi research. Yet, as frustrated as I am by this course and Harvey's instruction, I almost feel that YSPH is more to blame. I actually feel that Harvey does not realize how poorly taught this course was and do feel that he is genuinely a good guy who wants us all to appreciate epi. I am more frustrated by YSPH, who should either obtain an effective instructor for this required course or provide Harvey the resources that he needs to become a more competent instructor. Lastly, the TFs were an immensely redeeming quality of this course and were the most approachable, incredible group who imparted so much knowledge on this course. I don't know what I would have done without them but truly hope that YSPH seriously and critically evaluates this course for the future.... since it clearly hasn't been done yet.
The instructor can be more interactive with his teaching style.
Professor Risch is very dry and unapproachable.
Harvey is a great scientist, I hope he could interact more with students in the class

Strengths:
Lecture slides were clear

Weakness: 
Professor repeated text on slides verbatim for lectures 
Exam expectations were not made clear
Seemed as though HW and exam problems were designed to trick students 
Did not make material interesting
Decent.

Professor Risch has a clear strength in the fact that he knows analytical methods quit well, but I think he too often voiced his own opinion on current debates in the field without giving the time of day to the other side. Some class periods were spent with him detailing why he disagrees with current literature, which is great, but left students feeling somewhat uncertain on what we actually needed to absorb. Lectures were very informative but often quite text heavy. Overall, his expertise was clear, but the teaching methods may need to be a little more clear for the students.
good

As mentioned above, the way the class sessions were held failed to encourage students to participate and attend class sessions. I believe that Dr. Risch would actually benefit from utilizing a chalk-and-board technique. This would allow him to engage more with the students rather than having the crutch of power point slides. 

Dr. Risch is an extremely smart man and likely an asset to the YSPH community but that was not something demonstrated to us during this class.

The professor did not feel approachable. If anything, I felt like a nuisance to him when asking questions. It was incredibly inappropriate too that in every single lecture he found some way to imply the incompetence of other academics.
Only take this if necessary. Hopefully it will be better in the future.

I would recommend taking this course. The assignments helped me prepare for the exams well and the grading is also fair. It's just sometimes frustrating when the lecture slides don't explain concepts clearly.
This is an important course for students in any epidemiology concentration. You essentially delve deeper into the concept learned in Epi I. I learned a lot and recommend this course.
This is an intermediate-level epidemiology course focused on study design/methods and data analysis. I would highly recommend the course to anyone interested in epidemiology.
Highly recommend this course for non-EPI students.
Good foundation in Epi methods and application.
I wouldn't unless you are required to take it by your department. If there is a different professor, I would recommend. A good course to round out your epidemiology knowledge.
Recommended
No. If you're taking this course, you are probably required to, but I'd recommend waiting to take this course with another instructor if you can. Prof. Risch was not an effective instructor.

I would definitely recommend the course to anyone who is in epi and/or interested in research (I think all epi students at YSPH should take epi 2!). The skills you'd learn are valuable and help you become better at reading literature and understanding the nuances all of epi concepts presented in epi 1.

The course is difficult and requires a lot of hard work but you get what you put in it. I would definitely recommend it for anyone who wants a career in epidemiology or is interested in this field since it covers a lot of foundational stuff and helps you understand the field better.
Yes, I think every student that pursue an MPH degree should take this course. It introduces useful methods in research.
Critical if you want to pursue epidemiology. it is very hard to get used to the style of the course. Take your time and review.
Good technical course on epi. A good follow up to Epi 1.
Yes, recommend for the strength of the concepts learned.
I recommend.
Highly recommend
I would not, unfortunately, recommend this course to a fellow student as the lecture slides could have been less text-heavy and some exam questions were unfair in the context of this course.
Worth studying experience
Expands on basic epi knowledge, covers the bases, I didn't go to class excited each day but I am happy with what I learned overall
This a great class. If you want more epi, consider to take it. The materials covered in the class are so useful and practical.

This is a good course providing you with new perspectives and the ways of critical thinking. You will learn important but basic epi knowledge which would be essential in not only the field of epi but also some other fields like data analysis.  I would definitely recommend it.
Overall I learned a lot about Epi and the course was good. It was just very difficult to understand exactly what harvey wanted on his exams and hw's.
Good course for better understanding epi

it is a very useful subject especially within public health
I will say this is a useful class but be prepared for a huge amount of work.
I would not recommend this course to another student. Professor did not make the material interesting making lectures seem long and dull. Amount of work per week felt excessive.
Useful course.

The course is a deep dive into concepts learned in EPI 1, and is very much scaled up in difficulty. You will be invited to challenge the common practices in the field and truly sink your teeth into what is means to think critically through the epidemiological lens. Of course I think people studying epidemiology should take this course, but all other disciplines have so much to gain from taking it that I believe they should as well. If public health aims to be a truly interdisciplinary field, the more of us that have common training, the better.
I have never struggled to pay attention in a class like this. Made me want to change departments. Do not take unless you are very interested in epidemiology.
good

This class expands on the fabulous science of epidemiology from our Epi I class in fall semester. If you were interested in the varying complications that may arise in creating a study design and analyzing data, you will gain a lot from this course. However, if you have an option to take it from a different professor, I would take that path.
I would not recommend this course to other students. I walked away from this course more confused and less prepared in epidemiological methods than I was coming into the spring semester.
